answers.answer: Hi,Measuring the GGT provides a very sensitive indicator of the presence or absence of hepatobiliary disease. Raised GGT levels have been reported in a variety of clinical conditions including pancreatic disease, renal failure, diabetes, obesity, medication side effect and alcoholism. It is best that you discuss the results with your doctor for proper evaluation. A repeat test may be done to monitor the levels. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: Hi,I recently had blood testing done through my employer and my GGT level came back at 67 (0-65 normal for men). Everything else was in the normal ranges (ALP 67, AST 25, ALT 19).  Should I be concerned with the GGT result and should I have a follow up test done?  I don't generally exceed 12-14 drinks/week.  Additionally, I am a coffee drinker as well as having 1-2 diet sodas a day, and just take the regular vitamins (C, B12, E).  I have used Ginseng periodically.  The week before the test I think I had 4-5 drinks 5 days prior and 2 drinks 3 days prior.Does the GGT measurement change frequently and is it more weighted on recent drinking (last 2 weeks) or the average of the last month?  Is there any reason to re-test or be concerned?Thanks.
